Summary: What is Self-attunement? In this teaching on “The 7 Stations of Self-Attunement,“ Shunyamurti shares how to live a life true to the Will of the Divine. By increasing our intelligence, we can untie the knot that traps us in the lower chakras and use Reason to rise up the kundalini ladder to the realm of Pure Spirit. 

Shunyamurti honors Yom Kippur, the highest holy day of atonement with a teaching about (the 7 stations of) Self-attunement and the 7 turnings of Judaic Dharma.

Namaste.

Baruch hashem. Shalom!

Tonight, we are celebrating ErevYom Kippur. We’re entering the Jewish limb of the Tree of Life, and Sat Yoga is the final leaf on each branch of the tree, the final turning of the wheel of every Dharma. And so we have to celebrate all of them, and it seems appropriate, especially, to celebrate the highest holy day of the Jewish religion this year, which is the Day of—what the Jews themselves call—Atonement.

But I think that for Sat Yogis, on the seventh turning of Judaic Dharma, should refer to it as the “Day of Self-Attunement”. And so I’m going to be treating the day as, in terms of gyana, much more than a bhakti—although the two are intertwined in the ascension of consciousness into a state of true attunement with the Supreme Reality, with the Godhead. And so it’s a day of, indeed letting go of those lower levels in which the consciousness identifies with matter rather than with Spirit—which prevents attunement, and prevents atonement from being authentic, because the consciousness of the ego-mind that is split, and identified with the body, cannot remain attuned to God—of necessity, it will be pulled down back into a state of jouissance. And the jouissance, which is constituted by the lower three chakras—in particular, chakra two—but chakra two, when one analyzes it, is really a way of securing chakra one and chakra three—but those three chakras become a knot, and that knot is the chit jada granthi, and the Day of Atonement, which is classically, a day of cleansing oneself from one’s sins—that is the sin, because that is the fallen state from the higher chakras, particularly the supreme chakra of the ultimate Real.

And so it’s important to understand then how to become in resonance with that, and open the knot that has kept us as avowed jouissance-ists, and nihilists, and actually practically functionally atheists, even if we give lip service to the name of God, or some name, but the name is not the named. And so we must go beyond the Baruch Hashem, the blessed is the name, to what the name signifies. If we don’t reach the signified and the referent of the signified, then we fail to achieve what this day is about.

So, as you probably all know, the Israelites came originally from Kashmir, and A-Braham, along with Melcha Tzedek, were Shiva worshippers, but they immigrated to the land of Ur—which is in the Middle East, in Persia and Iraq—and there the worship was that of the icons, the idols of the gods and goddesses who were manifestations in Sat Yuga of God-consciousness; those who were attuned to the Self. But we are not allowed, according to Av Ram—and he was accurate in that—to attune to one who is attuned, but we must attune to That to which they are attuned. Right?

This is very important, that the resonance must be with the Real, not with any router of that Real. That is, let’s say, an interim, if one recognizes that one is attracted to is a being who is vibrating in attunement, but one must become attuned to That, and then recognize that That is not a phenomenon that has a local emanation, but is everywhere, omnipresent.

And so the forefather, Av Ram, took the Shiva lingam on his journey from Kashmir and said, “We don’t worship anything but that which is incorporeal.” The lingam representing the eternal flame, but the flame made into stone because on the mountains of India, the flames go out, but if you make an icon of a flame in stone, it becomes an eternal light—but a signifier of light, not the signified. And so Av Ram went back to creating a gathering place in which, once again, light, the  Ner Tamid, was installed as the object of meditation in what is now Palestine, and became ancient Israel. But those three founders—there were three generations of patriarchs—Av Ram, whose name was changed to A-Braham, the Braham was that of being a brahmin, and of his resonance with Brahman. And Brahman and Shiva in those times were not separated; they were not two concepts, they were a single conceptualization.

And then one of his great accomplishments was actually—it’s controversial—but how he was remembered is that he ended child sacrifice. You remember that scene in the Torah where he’s about—God tells him, “Kill your son Isaac.” Right? And he’s about to do it, but then at the last minute, God changes his mind, and then from then on, there is no more child sacrifice. And it was something that was current in the social order of that time in the Middle East, and this brought that into an end. And so this was the first turning of the Israelite Dharma, and the three patriarchs, ending with Ya’akov, Jacob, who became known as Yisra-El, “one who wrestles with God”, because of a true, let’s say, internal battle that was necessary for him to be able to become attuned to the Supreme Self, put them into a very special category. But at that time, there was no Torah, there were no mitzvahs, there was none of that; what there was, was friendship, openness. Avram was famous for having his doors open—they had four doors, one on each side, they were always open, and he accepted the stranger. So anyone who was a stranger in a strange land was welcome with him, and he became the wise man who became the founder of what became ultimately twelve tribes. So that was the first turning of the wheel.

(You know, Jagdish, are you sure you should be sitting cross-legged? Are you sure it won’t hurt your knees? No? OK, I don’t want anything to happen. Your knees are very valuable to us. I don’t know if we can get them insured, but we should.)

OK, back to my story. The second turning of the wheel happened after the Israelites fell to a lower level, and as God’s tendency is, he kicks them out. This time, he kicked them out into Egypt. And then the second turning of the wheel was that of Moshe, who led them out of Egypt and to the Mount Sinai, and that mountain, the symbol of the holy mountain that is on fire, that archetypal symbol, you will recognize, is also the symbol of Arunachala. And so it is the fiery mountain that is actually the archetypal form that every Israelite is to claim, you see, because the mountain is both the peak of consciousness—it’s the solidity, it’s the steadiness, it’s the silence, it’s the longevity—the mountain has many symbolic meanings—and the holy mountain, the Mountain of God, became a symbol that became present throughout all of the various dharmas.

Well, the Israelites, of course, didn’t sustain that attunement, and of course God kicked them out again after a while, but it was after a long line of prophets had warned them about this, but then they were taken captive and wept by the waters of Babylon. You all remember all of the Babylonian exile, etc.—they were, you know, God relented finally, and they were allowed back one more time. OK, how many strikes before you’re out?

Well, they had one more left, but then the Romans—well, they won a few battles with the Hasmoneans, but you see what happened with the Hashmonians, the Maccabees, you all remember, Israel was two united regions, Judea and Samaria, but the Samarians—who were often called Samaritans, “good Samaritans” often—the Samarians were Israelites. They were both equally, if you will, Jewish, although that term was not yet an appropriate one, but then they had a falling out, they fought and they denied each other, and that was the beginning of the end, this split, and then the loss of many tribes that disappeared. And then we had the Roman conquest and occupation; and for me, the third—are we on the third or the fourth? We have the first turning is the patriarchs, second is Moshe, I think the third turning is the prophets, because all of their writings were collected, they were the warners of the dangers of not following the spirit of the law, not just the letter of the law, and holding on to friendship among each other, unity of the group rather than schism, and they were not able to do that.

But I think then the fourth turning of the wheel under the Roman occupation was that of Rav Yeshua—the rabbi known as Jesus these days. But he was actually teaching, I think, the highest form of Judaism and holding on to that love of peace, of turning the other cheek, of walking a mile in the other’s sandals, and of truly living a life of altruism, and complete giving of oneself to the welfare of the whole, at the same time that one had become a pure instrument of that Supreme Reality.

But of course, that turning of the wheel was not accepted by many, but I do think it is the valid fourth turning. I would even say the fifth turning of the wheel then was later the turning made by the Sufis, because they are of the same Abrahamic tradition. Muslims are not other than from that same root via a son of Abraham; Ishmael was an equal son with Yitzkhaq.

So we have again a schism that there is an attempt to heal, especially with Rumi, he, I think, represents perhaps the high point of Sufism, in which he said, you know, “If my religion,” he said, “is a religion of love, you know, and you can call it Sufism if you want, you can call it Islam if you want, but if Islam is not a religion of love, then count me out.” That’s the religion. And I think that fits very much with the teachings of Jesus and with the teachings of Avraham.

So we have a unity there among those who are at the pinnacle of consciousness, but among the egos that were trying to take over all of these traditions, of course, peace became the last thing that they wanted. What they wanted was power, and they wanted jouissance, and they wanted the security of an empire. So things obviously went from good to worse, and we have a situation—Yom Kippur, by the way, historically was maybe one of the last, maybe the last holiday. The tradition is that it was there from the time of the march through the desert, but actually it was first mentioned, in any detail, in the writings of Josephus, which was during that time of the split between Samaria and Judea—both of which, both of these social groups that had now become split and antagonistic, celebrated Yom Kippur, but it had not been mentioned in earlier times. So it probably goes back to around 400 BC, or BCE, if you prefer.

But we’re dealing with a holiday of atonement for the sins that basically caused the Israelites, and then the Jews, to be kicked out in a final diaspora caused by the Romans to lose touch mostly with the Holy Land. A few remained, and the ones who remained became known as Palestinians, and eventually became Islamized, but they are really probably those who are descendants of the early Israelites, far more than the Ashkenazi Jews who came from Germany and Ukraine, and the Khazarian empire, to colonize the state of Israel in the twentieth century. But that’s a whole other story and I don’t want to get political tonight. I want to stay with the spiritual message.

And because of that, I want to really get into what Self-attunement is, but I do want to refer to two books that I want to read a little bit from, that are, I think, representative of two wings of modern Judaism, which are the Mitnagdim and the Hasidim. We’ve studied the Hasidim before—they were more of the mystical Jews who made secondary the Halacha, the laws, the Dharma, and primarily it was about ecstasy. And it was out of being in a state of ecstatic prayer that then one lived a life that was true to the Will of God, but it was much more of an Avadhuta ideal than it was an ideal of following any rulebound mode of intellectuality. But that other side of it has, I think, a tremendous value—the development of the intellect of the Jews since the days of the ghetto and all of that—the focus on intellectual development, I think, is what is maybe responsible for why you see so many Jews—many more than their numbers in the population—as famous scientists and philosophers and beings who have succeeded in many different fields; including the fields of becoming great Buddhists and Hindus, and becoming parts of a religious movement that was not as exhausted and turned into a kind of vapid intellectuality when the reformed Jewish movement came in, and the loss of that power of soul that was at the core of the Chassidus, of the desire to become on fire, literally, with the Presence of God.

So the two books I want to read a little bit from, one of them is by Jacob Neusner, a Jewish scholar, and the title is The Glory of God is Intelligence, and I think that there is some value in having that understanding that we are here to increase our intelligence. And the reason why I think it’s important for Sat Yogis is this: the chit jada granthi, the knot that ties us to the lower chakra ego identity, is tied via the imaginary register only, OK? It’s only the imaginary register that keeps us trapped in false consciousness. The symbolic register—and I’m speaking here of the higher symbolic, not the imaginarized symbolic—in other words, everyone can speak, use language, and pretend that they are making sense, but that’s not the same as the real use of reason that appears at the level of chakra five—but that is our true nature. That Chit of symbolic intelligence is what is able to untie the knot to the imaginary register that keeps us identified as being bodies in the world, rather than pure Spirit. So once we understand that the symbolic is a path to the Real—a very direct path, and that’s what gyana has always been about—then we can see that it is and has always been a gyana yoga path.

So I don’t think I’m going to read too much from it, but I think some of this is interesting from someone who is in a very, let’s say, pragmatic mode of Judaism. He says, “Above all, Judaic thinking at its best rejects gullibility and credulity. It is indeed peculiarly modern in its systematic skepticism, its testing of each proposition, not to destroy, but to refine what people supposed to be so. The Talmud’s first question, for example, is not who said so, but why? What is the reason?”

OK, so I want to ask you a question: what is the reason we have been given reason? Have you ever thought about that? OK, it’s a very important point, but this is the core of the Jewish rabbis’ (in a classical sense) goal, is to refine his or her capacity for reason to such an extent that one is able to read the Mind of God. And the Talmud is essentially, it’s a legal system, a system of understanding how to resolve disputes, that was brought about through debate between the leading wise men of the Jewish tradition to help in the diaspora, the communities—not to require to go to the non-Jewish legal system to solve their problems, but to do it from within the principles of those original understandings of our relationship to God and to reality.

He says, “The fruit of insight is inquiry. The result of inquiry is insight, in endless progression. The only road closed is the road back to the unarticulated, the unconscious, and the un-self-conscious. For once consciousness is achieved, a reason spelled out, one cannot again pretend that there is no reason, and nothing has been articulated. For the Talmud, the alternatives are not faith or nihilism, but reflection, or dumb reflex, consciousness, or animal instinct. Man in God’s image has the capacity to reflect and to criticize, all an animal can do is act and react.”

So it is this capacity to refine our reason that is the essence of the sadhana of the religious Jew. But to do it, as he says, “The Talmud, for its part, endures as a monument to intellectualism focused upon the application of practical rationality to society.”

So its interest is in creating social harmony. It pays tribute on every page to the human potential to think morally, yet without sentimentality; to reflect about fundamentals and basic principles, yet, “For concrete purposes and with ordinary society in mind, the good, well-regulated society will nurture disciplined and strong character. The mighty man, the one who has overcome his impulses, will stand as a pillar of the good society.”

So this is the goal: using reason to overcome the lower chakra tendency towards jouissance. And, “The ultimate use of practical reason to become an expression of the transcendent, which is within, not separated.” And it is reason that then creates a union of your mind with the Mind of God, because once your mind overcomes narcissism and egocentricity, then it becomes theocentric, and an entirely different level of intelligence is downloaded.

So I do think there’s a tremendous value in that focus—however, let’s look at the Hasidic view in contrast to that. Is this interesting to people? Is this OK to keep going? I don’t want to become too intellectualized in this celebration of Self-attunement, but I think it may help us to achieve our aim.

So the founder of modernism Hasidism is—and this is a book called The Tales of the Hasidim, by Martin Buber, who collected them from the earliest times, from the stories that were told by the Hasidim about their Rebbes. And the first Rebbe, the founder of the movement, was the Baal Shem Tov, the “Master of the Good Name”, and I want to read a few anecdotes, or stories about the Baal Shem Tov. The first one is the first one in the book, which I think, remember, we have to apply all of these teachings psychologically to ourselves; so it’s not simply a reference to a man who lived in Poland or Russia at a certain time—this is a reference to universal psychology.

“They say that once when all souls were gathered in Adam’s soul”—this is interesting because the Muslims say the same thing before, except they say that all the souls were gathered in Allah before the creation of Adam, but then through Adam, all of those souls ended up being born in time, and so it’s a very similar story or archetype.

“They say that once when all souls were gathered in Adam’s soul at the hour when he stood beside the tree of knowledge,” right? This is the knowledge of good and evil. This is the tree of duality. “At that hour, the soul of the Baal Shem Tov went away, and he did not eat of the fruit of the tree.”

OK? Now, this is very interesting. It means he did not have original sin, to use a Christian concept about the consequences of that. Right? The Baal Shem Tov remained innocent. He did not carry a burden of sin. OK? Now, why is that important? Because remembering what I just said, the burden of sin is carried not in the soul—it doesn’t say here that the Baal Shem Tov was the only soul who turned away—what I would say is, every soul is innocent of eating of that tree—but the ego ate of that tree, OK? It’s the ego that is that consciousness that is actually represented by the tree. And it is the ego that is constantly making judgments of good and evil, and those judgments themselves are evil because they have taken one out of attunement with God. It was the eating of that tree, of being in a dual, split mind, that was filled with moral judgments, that caused the loss of paradise.

But if the soul did not eat of that tree, and the soul is the negation of the ego, the non-egoic part of your consciousness—but that aspect of your consciousness that is more real than your ego, because it sustains its consciousness through many, many lifetimes—the soul, relatively, is eternal, from its first birth to the end of time. So if we understand that, then I think it gives us a way to not have to take the detour through the belief in being someone carrying a burden of sins, and that, to me, is the main obstacle that most people in the Ashram have: they’re carrying such a burden of sins that they do not feel worthy of eating of the Tree of Life, and of attuning to God, and so it is that that becomes the obstacle.

  1. The Baal Shem Tov said, “Before the coming of the Mashiach, (Messiah), there will be great abundance in the world. The Jews will get rich. They’ll become accustomed to running their houses in grand style, and moderation will be cast to the winds. But then the lean years will come, want, and a meager livelihood,”—it seems like we’re approaching the lean years in that sense—“and the world will be full of poverty. The Jews will not be able to satisfy their needs grown beyond rhyme or reason, and then the labor which will bring forth the Messiah will begin.”

OK, so we have to go through this time of tribulations, where not only the Jews of the first few turnings, but of all the turnings, have to go through the lean times. I don’t think it’ll be many years. I think it will get very lean, very fast, and we will have to attune to God in order to survive and to sustain consciousness. OK. It’s interesting, I put these markers in here years ago, I haven’t taken this book out of the shelf for years—I don’t know, maybe I’ve taught these before, but I don’t know if I did because we did have a Hasidic retreat years ago, right, it was many years ago now—but in any case, I’m going to read them again. Somehow they fit, so I didn’t need to find new ones today.

So this is the story of the Baal Shem’s son, after the Baal Shem died. “Sometime after my father’s death, I saw him in the shape of a fiery mountain which burst into countless sparks. I asked him, ‘Why do you appear in a shape such as this?’ He answered, ‘In this shape, I serve God.’”

OK, so this is very interesting, a human mountain, which is what Ramana also was, and what all of us are to be, and why the yogis go and meditate on mountaintops. All the Shiva temples are on mountains, and that is a manifestation of what has to be internalized with all of its implications.

OK, they asked Rabbi Pinchas, “Why is God called Makom?” which means “place”. “He certainly is the place of the world, but then he ought to be called that, not just place.” And the rabbi replied, “Man should go into God so that God may surround him, saturate him and become his place.”

I would go further and say and take His place, because if God is the place where you are, two things don’t exist in the same space, only one, and that one must be God, Adonai Echad. So, OK, one more. OK. Well, this one is about the Day of Atonement, it’s a bit long, but I think it’s interesting. And this is one of the middle generations of the Hasidim, a number of generations after the death of the Baal Shem Tov.

“On the eve of the Day of Atonement, rabbi Shmelke of Nikolsburg put on his prayer shawl, his tallit, and went to the house of prayer. On his way from the entrance to the Holy Ark, he called aloud the words of the Scriptures, ‘For on this day shall atonement be made for you, to cleanse you.’” That’s clearly the word of God. “And after that he quoted Rabbi Akiba’s words from the Mishnah before whom do you atone, and who cleanses you? Your father in heaven.’ And all the people heard him and burst into tears, it is said. When he stood in front of the ark, then he said, ‘Brothers of my heart, you must know that the core of turning, Teshuvah, turning to God, is the offering up of life itself.”

OK, that’s what the day of Atonement is about, the offering up of your life to God. If you really want to celebrate this holiday, that’s what you must do.

“For we are of the seed of Abraham, who offered his life for the sanctification of the blessed Name, and even if they would cast him into a lion kill, he remained firm. We are of the seed of Yitzkhak, who offered his life and laid his neck on the stone of the altar, and they are surely pleading to our Father in Heaven on our behalf, on this holy and awful day of judgment. But let us too walk in their tracks and imitate their works. Let us offer up our own lives for the sanctification of the name of he who is blessed. Let us unite and sanctify his mighty Name with fervent love, and with this as our purpose, let us say together Sh’ma Yisra-El, Hear oh Israel, and weeping the people said, ‘The Lord our God, the Lord is one.’”

Well, this goes on, but I’m not going to continue with it, but I’ll go to the last part of this story of this holy day. “In front of the open archive recited the confession of sins. All the people repeated after him word for word, and as they did so, they wept. He took out the scroll of the Torah, and holding it high in his hand, spoke to the congregation about the sins of man. But in the end he said, ‘You must know that the weeping we do on this day is un-blessed if it is filled with gloom, for the Divine Presence does not dwell in Heaviness,” heaviness of heart, “but only in rejoicing in the Commandments, and see, no joy is greater than the joy on this day when it is granted to us to drive all evil impulses from our hearts, through the power of turning to God, to come close to our Father in Heaven, whose hand is outstretched to receive those who turn to Him. And so all the tears we shed on this day should be tears of joy. As it is written, serve the Lord with fear and rejoice with trembling.”

Interesting paradox: fear and joy. You can only have joy if you have fear of God, fear of losing that attunement—the attunement brings the joy, the fear of losing it keeps one steady in that focus.

So how many people like the Hasidim? They have a very beautiful, almost Zen koan-like approach to their teachings. OK, now this is the one I want to focus on for this evening. “A disciple asked Rabbi Shmelke, ‘We are commanded to love our neighbor as ourself—how can I do this if my neighbor has wronged me?’ The Rabbi answered, ‘You must understand, these words are right—love your neighbor like something which you yourself are. For all souls are one. Each is a spark from the original soul. And this soul,”—God, right? The Paramatman—“is wholly inherent in all souls, just as your soul is in all the members of your body. It may come to pass that your hand makes a mistake and strikes you, but would you then take a stick and chastise your hand because it lacked understanding, and thus increase your pain? It is the same if your neighbor, who is of one soul with you, wrongs you for lack of understanding. If you punish him, you only hurt yourself.’ The disciple went on asking, ‘But if I see a man who is wicked before God, how can I love him?’ ‘Don’t you know,’ said Rabbi Shmelke, ‘that the original soul came out of the essence of God and that every human soul is a part of God? And will you have no mercy on him when you see that one of his, of God’s holy sparks, has been lost in a labyrinth and is almost stifled? Will you not uplift him with your love?’”

Now, I think this Jewish teaching is extremely relevant in a time of Fauci, and Gates, and Schwab, and Biden, Trump, Von der Leyen—you can include Putin if you want—you can include anyone—are you able to love them unconditionally? Are you able to love the deep state? The cabal? The aliens are also children of God, all of them. Are you able to have unconditional love without duality, without eating of that tree of good and evil? Because that is our duty. It’s a very high teaching.

At the close of the “72nd Psalm are the words, ‘And let the whole earth be filled with His glory. Amen. Amen.’ The prayers of David, the son of Jesse, are ended. This is the last of the psalms. Concerning this, Rabbi Levi Yitzhak said, ‘All prayers and hymns are a plea to have his glory revealed throughout the world, but if once the whole world is indeed filled with that glory, there will be no further need to pray.’” There will be no further need for religion, no further need for Judaism, no further need for any technique to attune, because we ourselves will realize we are the glory of God. This is the time in which the glory must be revealed, and only if we give our lives—meaning, kill the ego—to become truly alive, can we fulfill that mitzvah.

“Rabbi Bunam told this story. He said, ‘When the Baal Shem Tov made the first Hasidim, the evil urge, the yetzer hara,”—which is like the devil for the Jews—“was in great straits,” right? The devil was upset. “For as the devil said to his followers, now those Hasidim of the Baal Shem Tov will set the world ablaze with their holiness.’ But then the devil thought of a way out. He disguised himself, he pretended to be someone else, and he went to two Hasidim who lived together in a certain town. He said to them, ‘Your work is very praiseworthy, but there ought to be at least ten of you, so you can pray in a quorum, right, a minyan. He fetched eight of his people and joined them to those two, he fetched eight of his people and joined them to those two Hasidim, and then, since they had no money to purchase a scroll and other things they needed, he brought them a rich man, also one of the devil’s adherents, who provided them with whatever was necessary. He did the same everywhere. When he had finished, he said to his hosts, ‘Now we no longer need be afraid of anything, for we have the majority, and that is what counts.’”

Alright. “Rabbi Yitzhak was asked, ‘What do you think was Adam’s real sin?’ ‘Adam’s real sin,’ said he, ‘was that he worried about the morrow.’ The serpent set out to reason with him. ‘There’s no service you can perform because you cannot distinguish between good and evil. You’re unable to make a choice. What good are you? Eat of this fruit and you’ll be able to distinguish. You’ll choose the good and you’ll receive the reward.’ So then that he gave ear to this, Adam. This is where Adam was at fault. He worried that he would not be able to serve. And yet, at that very hour, he had his service to obey God and resist the serpent.”

It’s a beautiful paradox, right? We fell out of our desire to serve, to be good. OK, last ones.

“Someone asked the Rabbi of Ger, ‘Why do people always weep when they say the words of the prayer? Man, his origin is of the dust, and his end is in the dust. If man sprang from gold and turned to dust, OK, you could weep, that would make sense, but not if he returns whence he has come. The Tsadik replied, ‘The origin of the world is dust, but man has been placed in it that he may raise the dust to spirit. But man always fails in the end, and everything crumbles into dust.’”

Will we fail this time? It’s our last chance not to fail.

“The Rabbi of Ger said on another occasion, ‘Why is man afraid of dying? For does he not then go to his Father?’ ‘What man fears is the moment he will survey from the other world everything he has done on this earth.’”

So our real fear that keeps us from choosing liberation is facing the unbearable truth of those sins that our ego committed, and this is the catch-22 that causes the failure of all religions, and why Kali Yuga religions could not prevent the fall into the final apocalyptic moment that we’re in. And all of those religions are religions of the body, really. You know, you’re only a Jew if your mother’s body was Jewish. It’s not a religion of pure Spirit; you’re identified via the body. And this is what, in a sense, Christ came to change and said, no, there’s no difference between the Greek and the Jew and the barbarian and all of that—it’s a matter of circumcision of your heart, not of the body. And it’s a matter of your faith, and your love, not a matter of your bodily descendants. The same thing happened with the Hindus whose religion is carried on the matrilineal succession. And Buddhism said, no, it’s not like that, anyone can become a buddha, it’s a question of consciousness not being born in the brahmin caste, right? There’s no caste system in Buddhism. But even those religions then became religions that you would be born into: you’d be baptized a Christian right after birth. You wouldn’t be given a choice later in life. You were put into that before you could use your reason and your intelligence to make your decision. And in the same way, with all of the religions, there was an indoctrination before one’s capacity to think had matured sufficiently to make a reasoned choice.

And because of that, the ego’s identity is controlled by the big Other. It’s controlled by the internalized superego parents who make you feel guilty if you shift your paradigm out of the belief system that they gave you. And so that burden of sin is not a burden of sin in relation to God, but in relation to the superego that has taken the place of God in the imaginary register. So this is the issue.

So because of this, I want to give a Sat Yoga approach to this day. Let’s call it The Seven Stages of Self-Attunement.

The first stage is the stage that you reach when you cross the threshold into a wisdom school, and you are told that Sri Ramana’s technique, if you will, his approach, is simply to ask yourself, “Who are you? Who am I?” Right? That’s it. You are simply to wonder, “Who am I?” Most people who enter the spiritual field never are able to establish themselves at this station because they do not question who they are. They assume that they’re a bodily being who was born at a certain time to certain parents, and you have certain attitudes and certain beliefs and certain obligations to family, society, culture, religion, whatever. You have an identity already, and there is hardly anyone who will challenge that identity.

And so most people who take up atma vichara do not do it authentically because they do not question their ego identity. They do not sincerely authentically question “Who am I?” And so they will constantly be obsessed by the sins of their past, their inadequacies, their failings, their traumas, their missing out on whatever—their yearning for some kind of jouissance they didn’t get—whatever it might be, and usually all of the above and more; it’s part of an identity structure that is never questioned. And if you don’t question that, you can’t get, even, to the second station.

How many of you sincerely question your identity, really wonder who you are, not just make a show of it and think, “Yes, of course I know who I am, I wish I were someone different, but I’m not and I can’t, and therefore I flagellate myself, and I try to get better, and I try to be more disciplined, and lift more weights and get stronger, and try to be a little friendlier”, or whatever that you might try to do, but maybe not even that—but the point is, very few people here have reached the first station and truly question who you are. So how can the spiritual process begin?

OK, if you do, you get to the second station. The second station is the famous Neti Neti: “not this, not this”. This is when you really question—now, most people do say, “Oh yeah, I’m not the body, I’m not the mind”, and they make it into some ritualistic repetition of a mantra; that’s not really what neti neti is. Neti neti really means “I get it that I’m not the ego, that I’m not the mind that’s thinking, those emotions it’s having are not mine, those drives, those urges are not mine. I am not any of that which appears in my mind—none of those mental structures, objects, paradigms, none of it is who I am.” And until you get that, that you do not exist as the person you think you are, that is a fiction—until you realize that, you will not establish yourself in the opening—this is the portal to realization, at least of the soul, rather than of the ego, as a higher level of your identity.

But what happens to the ego that seriously questions, “Who am I?” They suddenly start to think that the world is not real. They suddenly start to think that they’re in some strange, surreal hallucination, and paranoia comes in. If you really question your identity and you’re still in the ego, paranoia will come in, a fear of depersonalization. There will be an attack. You may not notice it because you’ll want to soothe that so quickly, you don’t actually feel and recognize what is going on, but you’re being attacked by your Censor that produces a paranoid response of fear, of madness: “If I go any further, if I realize I don’t exist, that I’m not anything that I thought I was, I was never born, I’m not this body”—if you take that really seriously and actually imperience it, the ego will go crazy. It will do anything to stop you from that letting go of the identity structure.

And so it takes tremendous courage to proceed with the neti neti until you have unraveled all of the attachments to the signifiers of ego identity, and all of its narratives have been dropped from your mind once and for all. That’s the cleansing of the sins, realizing that there is no sin that pertains to you. And by sin, it’s any disappointment, any feeling of inadequacy, unworthiness, or any sense of human failing. All of that is in the imaginary register; doesn’t mean it didn’t happen within the fictional world of your ego bubble, but when that bubble is popped, it has no relevance to who you are. That’s why you shouldn’t have heaviness when you are praying, because the real one who is engaged in prayer, if the prayer is authentic, is the soul, not the ego, not the imaginary, and the soul is in joy, even though it’s trembling until its ego bubble is popped, but it’s in joy because it knows it is free of sin. It never ate of that tree.

OK, if you do graduate, then you get to the third station, which I’ll call Shunyata. This is the first Emptiness of the Buddhists, of the second turning of their Wheel of Dharma. This is the realization that not only is your identity completely empty of your real nature, it’s not yourself; your ego is not yourself. It’s a structure, a movie, a narrative, a game, a video icon that you’re using in this game, but you’re the player, the user of the icon, not the icon itself. So it’s that Emptiness. And that Emptiness you realize is the Emptiness of the whole world. None of it is real; all of it is your own projection. And so the Shunyata is the dropping of all projections, not just on your own ego, but on every ego, and on the world itself as a dream. And so one lets go of attachment to the dream and then one finds the dream.

So Shiva is the fourth station, the realization of Shiva, but it’s not yet Paramashiva—comes then the dreamer of the dream as Ishvara. But there is still duality in the sense that the fullness that becomes apparent within the Emptiness—that fullness of the presence of Shiva—is felt as a gift of grace that you are receiving. So there’s still duality of “me” and Shiva. OK, “I’m with Shiva, my emptiness as an ego now has given space, Makom, the space for Shiva to fill and take my place.” But there are still two in this station.

Then there’s a Trinity. The two becomes three, really, because what you recognize is that there is not only Shiva, but Shakti. Nara means the human level. This is your consciousness as a being in the matrix, but you recognize that the matrix itself is simply the Mind of Shakti, the Mind of God is the Goddess. And it is that power of the Goddess that has brought you into this embodied state in which you realize that the whole world is the vibrational emanations and the collapsed wave functions of those vibrations produced by a Supreme Intelligence. This is Shakti. And the field itself, the Brahman, that’s Shiva. And Nara is the one who is both the created one and the one in whose mind the creator appears. OK? So one’s mind becomes a trinity, the Holy Trinity, in the same way as the Christian Trinity, and it’s also there in the Trikaya theory of Buddhism.

The Trikaya theory has an interesting paradox that I want to really have you focus on, because it’s a significant contradiction that needs to be penetrated through a very deep meditative practice. And this is this: the Dharmakaya, that’s the Brahman, if you will, the place that the cosmos appears in, this is the ultimate field, and it’s that pure Intelligence, this is the ultimate body of the Buddha, the Buddha nature. Then there’s the Sambhogakaya. This is the bliss body. Sambhoga—bhoga is, right, “enjoyment”; Sam-bhoga, the “bliss”. And that “bliss body”, we could say, is the soul of Buddha-consciousness, which contains the intelligence, the liberated Chit, liberated from the granthi. But then there’s the Nirmanakaya. The Nirmanakaya is the actual person who was referred to as Buddha—whether it was Shakyamuni, or Gautama, or Siddhartha, I don’t care who you call him—but the point, is it’s a human person, a material body.

Now, in the second turning of the wheel, they said every material body is empty of Self-nature. Does that mean that the Nirmanakaya is also empty of Self-nature? But how can the Buddha fail to have Buddha-Nature? Is it possible that the Buddha as a material being is actually clueless about his Buddha-hood? He had to go through a period where he practiced his ascetic practices, right, he had to go through a long period of training and sadhana when he was clueless. And then, finally, the Nirmanakaya was connected to the Sambhogakaya and the Dharmakaya. So there is a paradoxical contradiction. Each of you is the Nirmanakaya of Buddha, but it is not yet attuned to the other two bodies. This is where the day of attunement is so important, but, of course, it must be every day.

So, almost done. Then we get the unity, at six. Let’s just call it Unity Field. What happens is, as you’re meditating in this state of a total worship and feeling of connection to Shakti and to Shiva, who are the two polarities of the Real—they are two powers, but they are also one, because the emanations of Shakti come from Shiva, but She becomes separate because She becomes the world, and Shiva is the transcendent, unmanifest; they are two polarities of reality. Both of those exist in your mind, OK? So the mind has to realize it is not a separate being worshipping Shiva and Shakti, but the mind itself—you could even think of the two hemispheres of the brain, one is Shakti, one is Shiva, but the brain is whole. But that’s what you contain, are these two energies, the manifest and the unmanifest, the capacity to manifest, to dream, and the capacity to be in deep sleep. And then there is the awakening to that fact that you are Shiva-Shakti in union, you are the unitive field.

And then the final state is that you realize the source of the feeling, which I’ll call Parama Shiva, the supreme level of Shiva, which is inconceivable, cannot be spoken about, but this is the final state. So in this level, you go from three and you realize that 3 = 2 = 1. And here you have 1 = 0. And then finally, Zero equals Infinity. Alright? So this is mathematics by yogic standards, and that realization has to be understood. And all the religions have that. The trinity are three in one, but they are not separate, and ultimately the one is Zero.

So these are the seven stations, I would say, of Sat Yoga’s version of what we should be doing on the Day of Atonement, and that day should be recognized as happening every day.

Now, I’m going to answer one other question that I had been asked, and this is how you get to that in the quickest possible way. And that is this: alright, here’s your ego.

Shunyamurti draws on the whiteboard.

You got three states: sleep, dream and waking, right? But now, I want to call this Waking 1. It’s the first kind of awakening, because you’re actually still asleep, because you’re in a fictional character living a life that isn’t your own authentic life. Around this is Waking 2. This is the Turiya state, when you have awakened from the three avastas. And remember: what does “Buddha” mean? “The awakened one.” It doesn’t mean it’s just somebody who heard the alarm clock and got up. It’s not that kind of awakening, is it? It’s the awakening from the illusion that he was a body, and the realization of being God, or the Buddha-Nature, if you prefer, or Brahman, or whatever. But it is that realization. So Turiya, the difference between Waking 2 and Waking 1, is, for the ego, those three avastas are always separate. You cannot be wide awake and asleep at the same time as an ego. And the more sleepy you are, the less awake you are. Right? They are reciprocals, but you cannot be fully in all three or even two. There is a contradictory drive that will make one dominant and the other recessive. You can train perhaps to be able to stay more conscious when you’re dreaming or that kind of thing, but nonetheless, they will always remain as three, separate. But in the Waking 2, waking, dream, and deep sleep are a unified field. You’re always in all of them simultaneously because you’re asleep to maya, you have the dream of Shakti going on, right? And you’re awake to the presence of the ultimate reality.

And then, of course, you have Waking 3 out here. Waking 3 is the Turiyatita state. The Turiya state which we can relate to the soul is still focused around the ego. The soul is not the ego, but it’s still concerned with the ascension of the ego, with its purification. In Waking 3, you have left it all behind, now you’re in the infinite, and what happens to your ego or your body—it’s not yours anymore, it’s irrelevant. It’s all part of God, and there’s no concern for your personal fate. And there’s no reaction when your environment isn’t perfect for you. If there’s too much noise or the food doesn’t have enough salt, or there’s a problem here or there, you do not react, you don’t get upset, you don’t project, you don’t collude with other egos, you don’t have attitudes and opinions. You don’t carry shame and guilt, or project them on other people. You don’t do any of those things—that’s the liberated state, when none of those sanskaras are ever active again, they don’t exist. They’ve been extinguished. You have entered the entire ocean and that little bubble that you thought you were is so far from your true nature that whether it pops or not doesn’t even matter, but you are already in another quantum leap to a different dimension of the Real, from which you will never return to mere bubble status, because you have encountered your infinite Self, and the bliss and the knowledge, and the power, and the freedom, are overwhelming and there would never be any drive to lose that and fall into forgetfulness of who you are.

Namaste,

Shunyamurti
