Summary: Shunyamurti introduces the nine parallel spectra of sameness and difference to help us find the madhyamaka of mind that fuses all states of consciousness into the Mind of God–overcoming all sameness and difference by bringing eternal life into time. This is the alchemy of Sat Yoga.

Today I want to talk to you about what’s different. There is a core issue in every ego-mind between the valorization of sameness and difference. And people are always, at the ego level, noticing what’s different, and at the soul level they’re looking for what’s the same. And this conflict between these two values consists and creates the major obstacles to liberation. But it’s very important that you recognize that the obstacles to liberation constitute the path to liberation.

So, I was going to come at 4am, but I was told to take down more dictation, so I’m just going to transmit it to you, and we’ll see where it goes.

The ego structure and the ego values and the ego dynamics have morphed over time in Kali Yuga. In earlier yugas, you didn’t even have ego; you had soul consciousness, and then beyond that you had pure Spirit. But in Kali Yuga—in early Kali Yuga—in that period they call the “Axial Age”, what was valorized by sages and the social order—that was in a sense governed by, or at least led by, the wisest beings, and the values that enabled society to become harmonious, and be sustainable, was originally the value of the Unmanifest.

So, because every manifest being was serving the Unmanifest, it provided a kind of sameness that accepted all the differences of the people within the society, who were all loyal to a particular unmanifest Real, that was the energy and the intelligence that they accepted was the glue that holds us together. And then by the time we get to middle Kali Yuga the Unmanifest drops out for most people in the world, and the values become that of—the chief value, becomes that of sameness and consistency, right?—because you have to have a consistent dharma to be able to create a society, or a community, in which promises can be kept, in which expectations can be met, in which everyone knows what they have to do in order to be approved of, in order to be adequate, in order to be good, in order to be appropriate within the context of that social order, right?

So that produces, then, that value of acting in accord with a standard—with an archetype—and there were a variety of archetypes available, as the society became more complex, from a simple tribal organization into a society with the division of labor, and then you would have various different archetypal forms, but each caste, each guild, each level of society, and the two genders, were all in accord with the archetype that signified the ideal form that they were to manifest. And this was the basis of worship—because worship, you know, is a contraction of the words “worth” and “shape”.

So, you went to the temple or to the gathering place, the council meeting, in order to shape your worth in accord with the archetype that was being given to you when you entered into adulthood, and into your profession, or your calling, your vision quest, whatever—but you understood clearly what it meant to be whoever you were to be. You had a role that was defined, not by the manifest group, but by the archetypal beauty, sense, dharmic criteria for what was excellence. And you knew what nobility was, and you knew what ignobility was. And so, it was very clear how to live; there weren’t any doubts or any questions or any kind of alienation.

But then, in late Kali Yuga, sameness fell away as a value, and difference became the primary value. And this happened with the rise of the West. The East stayed with sameness as their primary value, whereas the West chose difference. And so naturally, the West evolved differently—faster—it changed, it kept on changing, because it was based on change, on becoming different from what it was a moment ago. Different, always different, growing, changing, developing technology, and therefore developed a capacity to dominate the East and the South, for that matter. So, the West, which is also the North, became the dominant power during that imperialistic period that has also now fallen away, or is in its last legs that are now being fought out. But we have—and difference at its ultimate phase becomes total chaos, in which there is no longer any pattern that can be sustained, right? So, this happens at the macrocosmic level, and it happens at the microcosmic level, and until one can understand and integrate that conflict it’s very difficult to be in harmony with yourself, because you are split between these values.

So, the ego in late Kali Yuga is constituted by the love of difference; perhaps I should say the desire for difference. The ego wants to be as different from everyone else as possible—this is the whole individualism complex of the West, OK? However, within that, in the early modern period when the genders were still regulated, the role of the man was to hold a place of sameness, and the role of the woman was to be difference, right?

So, women would want different kinds of dresses and clothes and styles. The man is still these days wearing the suit and tie, and very boring, right, always the same. Every woman is different, and all men are the same. That’s no longer the case now that we’re in a transgendered reality, but there’s enough remnants of it that you can still relate to it, and that’s why, of course, you know, a man can eat the same meal every day of his life, he doesn’t care, but a woman, one night it has to be French cuisine, the next night it’s an Italian dinner, the next night she wants Chinese food, you know, it doesn’t stop. The woman has to have something different and new, because she’s bored with sameness. And so, she gets bored with her man very easily.

So, the one who is centered on the value of difference has fear of boredom. The one who is centered on sameness has fear of lack, because, in a way, he’s being left behind. But it’s also true the other way around, that the more different one becomes when one shifts out of a certain context—like, for example, women can be different in the sense of no two women want to wear the same dress to the ball, right? That’s a horror, right? You have to have a different one, but you don’t want to be so different that you’re not recognizable as the woman, right? So, you want to stay within a certain sameness that is the archetype of feminine beauty, but you want to be able to be in that with an entirely unique style, because there isn’t one form of beauty; there isn’t one, like, there is with the male form of sameness who, you know, the woman just wants him to be consistent, make a living, you know, support the family, and it’s fine that he eats the same gruel every day, and it makes it life easier for her—but she’s decorating the house all day and making it different, right, and doing all of that—but difference gets to be flighty, whereas the man has to be grounded and boring, and make sure the bills get paid. But the woman doesn’t—in the traditional household, we’re talking—that the woman doesn’t have to do all of that and can focus on flights of fancy.

So, these days, every ego wants to be in a flight of fancy and doesn’t want to be grounded, and can’t deal with Real 1, so the ego is totally obsessed with difference, but the soul still loves sameness, because difference, when it loses touch with sameness, it feels too ungrounded, so, it wants to have—to be able to touch base with someone who is consistent, but not have to be consistent themselves, but know that there is a home they can return to, where they’ll always be accepted, no matter how different they’ve become, right? And the parents will always take you back in, you know, and you can always be accepted, no matter if your hair is pink or purple or you’ve shaved it or whatever—the difference is irrelevant to this system that sustains the sameness, right?

So, the Self is unconditional love. The Self is love in itself. It doesn’t love sameness or difference, but it’s in a state of acceptance. But the lover of difference does not want sameness, and to the ego that loves difference, liberation is a boring sameness, you know? There are no great parties in nirvana! There’s no rock music there, there’s not even classical music, right? It’s boring, silent, stillness—who wants that? Right? So, when you are told to meditate and reach stillness, the ego says, “What? I’m going to just start chattering to myself! I don’t care what he’s saying, I’m not going to stop my thoughts because my thoughts are much more interesting to me than just having a silent mind.”

How many people feel that way? We have some honest people here, that’s good. So, it’s not an inability to have stillness, it’s just the ego is not interested in it. OK, so the ego doesn’t want liberation—that’s the last thing on its agenda. In fact, it’s not even on its bucket list—after it kicks the bucket it might be interested in that, you know, but not before. So, it will listen to the Tibetan Book of the Dead after it’s left the body and say, “OK, maybe I’ll try in another life.” But even there, you know: “Nah, nah it’s too boring. I’ll come back and do another life, and you know, and have another party”, right? So, the ego cannot abide stillness, because that’s death.

But eventually the ego reaches a point of the exhaustion of its creative potential to continue to become different. It becomes stale and stagnant, and it begins to fall from that rajasic state of constant difference into the tamasic state. And in the tamasic state, it starts to lose its flexibility, it gets rigid, it gets more angry and bitter, and it loses its life energy. And when that starts to happen, then it begins to change its attitude. Then it feels like it wants something different, it would prefer sattva to tamas. But in that state, it’s terrified that because of all of its rejection of God—who is represented by sameness to the ego-mind—that because it knows it cannot be liberated on its own power, it has to depend on grace. It feels, “I’m never going to get God’s grace. I don’t deserve it. Why would God give me grace? There’s all these saints around me. Me? I’m a sinner. I’m bad. I went into all of those marginal places in life and didn’t follow the dharma for one day, you know, and screwed all authority, was completely antagonistic to order, you know, God is not going to find me delicious or want to swallow me. No way! He’s going to leave me here.”

So that question of difference then becomes a fear of the absence of grace. And the other fear is that not only is there absence of grace, but there’s an absence of God, because the ego, in its obsession with difference and phenomenality, lost touch with the belief that there even is a noumenal plane. And if there is a God, it’s just an impersonal, you know, field of light without any love or anything to create value—it’s just loss. And so that sense of not wanting to lose consciousness keeps one in a mode of rejection, of doubt, and of fear of the lack of grace.

This makes sense to people so far? OK, so we’re getting into the psychology of what is the obstacle. So not only that, but the ego itself, because in the modern form—not necessarily any longer for the POMO [postmodern] form—but the modern form that’s still sufficiently present, that we get it: you have the conscious, you have the Censor in between, right—we have the Soy Burger and then the subconscious fantasies below that. The core of the ego is the Censor. The Censor is not another. The conscious mind thinks that it’s being victimized by the Censor, but the Censor is the authentic self. We had a question about authenticity—the Censor is the authentic self, not the conscious mind that says it wants this or that. And that’s why Freud discovered that authenticity only arises ever, in the world of egos, as a Freudian slip. Authenticity arises as a mistake, an accident, an error, or a symptom in the body that the person doesn’t want but that is expressing something that’s there: “Oops!”, right? So, authenticity is never a conscious way of being for the ego, and it doesn’t even really aspire to authenticity because it wants to keep its cards hidden from the other, and you’d have to be transparent to be authentic, and you’d have to reveal everything. People don’t want to reveal how much money they have in the bank, you know, who they really care about, what they really plan to do next, you know, everyone has ulterior motives that are in the back pocket. They’re not going to be divulged, right?

So, the Censor, however, is not accessible to the conscious mind. So, the ego, because it’s not, as the conscious mind, it’s not authentically itself—it’s different from itself because its conscious mind doesn’t know what its own censor wants. Its conscious mind is given a script and it’s told what to say, but it doesn’t even mean what it says, but it knows this is what it has to say. It’s kind of like a press secretary to a president, you know, it’ll say the things that it’s supposed to say but that’s not really the policy, you know. But that’s public relations. That’s all your conscious mind is, is PR, and it has no clue as to what your own policies are. It usually finds out later and says, “Was that what I wanted?” Right? And of course, it ends up in a horrible tangle because what the Censor wants usually has no relationship to reality and what reality can offer.

The ego, however, as Kali Yuga comes more and more toward its close, becomes more and more complex. OK, so the duality of sameness and difference begins to morph. It develops other axis or other parallel spectra, right—like sameness and difference is on a spectrum, but the ego, as it begins to relate to the soul and to the Self, once it’s in that exhausted state and decides it has to grow vertically, not just horizontally, to get out of its suffering—then it begins to develop nine different parallel spectra.

So, I’m going to read them to you. If somebody wants to write it on the board, you could. The global one is Nirvana/Samsara.

Right. Nirvana is the equivalent of ultimate sameness, and samsara is ultimate multiplicity and difference. But here it’s in an ontological state that brings one into the awareness that there is a transcendent possibility.

The second one is between Being and Becoming. And becoming includes both doing and having. I’m probably writing way too fast for you, but you tell me if you want me to repeat something, Swati, OK?

And, so again, there are some people who will choose to be on the side of being, and be as consistent and reliable and the same every day, in order to be able to ground something, that you have to sacrifice difference; whereas the one who is in a state of becoming is allowed to, even valorized, to come up with new ideas and be different.

So, there are the creative types, and then you have the accountants, you know, and the chief executives, and you don’t want the ones who are running the show to be totally flighty and becoming different, but you do want a creative department of people who are thinking differently, but they have to be modulated as to how many of those differences can we actualize, and which ones do we say, “OK, great idea, but not realistic, or we can’t afford it, or we have higher priorities”, alright? So all of these questions have to be integrated and harmonized, these different values. “Yeah, let’s get a hundred chickens and have all the eggs we want. Wait a minute, we don’t have enough people to handle all of those. We can only afford to get ten or twelve, or do we get thirty or forty?” All of these have to do with questions of sameness and difference, and being and becoming, and what are our capacities to deal with the differences, the changes that any new idea is going to create and shift all of the other priorities, and all of the other duties and necessities. So, this becomes a major focus of many people’s professional lives, right?

And then the next morphing is that of Necessary and Contingent. In theological terms, God is the one necessary Being. Everybody else is contingent. In other words, it might have been that you didn’t exist, right? There’s no law saying you have to exist, that God had to create you or make you exactly the way He did. Everything about every one of us is totally contingent, right? And could have been different, and could still become different. But God is a necessary Being who never changes. That’s the ground, the bedrock, right?

But even on the relative plane, everyone wants to be as necessary as possible, right? “I want to be needed. I want to be indispensable. If I’m contingent I can be fired, alright. I can be let go of.

They don’t need me. They’ll put me in a closet, and they’ll go on without me, right? So, I have to remain au courant with my capacity to function in order to be necessary.” So, this is also one of those spectra that the individual is always trying to measure, you know? “How needed am I, and how important am I, and how…”—whatever, right, in that category of essential cogs in the wheel of a social order.

And then the next one is Subject and Object, because some people want to have a totally subjective outlook on the world, others need to have an objective outlook. Some people want to be the object of desire, others want to look at the object of desire, right? Some want to go to the peep show and others want to perform, and some are exhibitionists, and some are hiding. But you have this question of subject/object that shows up in many ways, and one is always living on a spectrum between those, of what is shown and what is hidden. “What is my subjective opinion about this, and what is objectively the consensus”—and trying to modulate between those two conflicting polarities.

And then you have in general the Inner and Outer. “What is more important, my inner reality or what it looks like in my outer reality? Do I have to have a well-made bed, or can it be messy and I’m just comfortable on it and I don’t need to spend time doing that?” Right? “Is my inner reality, is it more important for me to meditate or clean the house, you know, or do other things?” Right? People have to make decisions between this. But what is most important? And even in my inner reality there’s an inner and outer. “Is it my mind that is most important and the development of my thoughts and my understanding at a symbolic and logical level? Or is it the silence, stillness, and repose, that is never affected?” You know, there’s an inner and outer within the inner that one is always within. So, there are fractal levels of all of these that go deeper and deeper, and higher and lower, right? Is this all making sense to people still? OK, tell me when it stops making sense. Any minute now, I’m sure.

And then you have the duality of Yin and Yang, OK. And yin and yang, you know, we could define that in a lot of ways—it’s not just active and passive, it’s not just superior and inferior, it’s not just convex and concave, but it has that relationality in which, when one is interacting with someone else, one is yang and the other is yin, and they may shift their positions in other kinds of activities, you know, for playing football, I might be more yin than someone else, but if we’re having a debate, I might be more yang than someone else, right? And we might find different areas where people’s, yin and yang are compatible, and other areas where they’re competing and they’re actually unable to coordinate their activities, because each one wants to be the boss, or each one wants the other one to make the decisions or whatever else. But the yin and yang aspect can either create wonderful harmony and make life a dance, or it can create loggerheads, right?

Still with me? Making sense? OK, so everyone’s got to work their way through navigating where they stand in all of these spectra, and how flexible they are to shift within each one and in relationship to every other person that they are interacting with in relation to all of them, right? So, life gets very complicated, even though most people aren’t thinking this out consciously, you know, “Where am I with this?” But there’s an intuitive way that people fit together, right—or don’t, and then become conflicted.

Then there’s Light and Dark. And I mean that in, of course, the sense, you know, of film noir, the dark values, the antihero versus the hero. You have these kinds of different types of scenario that become interesting. Is it a detective story? Is it a crime situation that has to be figured out? Or is it a romance? Or is it, you know, a pirate film? What are we in exactly, right? And so, your approach to life will depend on whether you are more on the bright side of life—even if you’re being crucified—or on the dark side, even if you’re the one nailing the guy on the cross. So, there is a consideration of your sense of wearing the white hat or the black hat.

So, the ninth one actually has five parts.

(Shunya in dialogue with student who is writing on whiteboard and missed one.)

Oh. How many do you have? Wait a minute. Which did you miss?

Becoming/Necessary? Contingent, Inner/Outer. You have Yin/Yang. Yeah. You have that? (Student responds) No, that was the same. OK, maybe there’s only eight, OK. I might have made—I’m different from myself, you know, I’ll apologize for it, but maybe not, because I do think that the Doing and Having can be another one, but in any case, it’ll turn out that there’s actually about thirteen, because the last one is Good and Not Good. OK that’s the spectrum, but good and not good can appear in five different ways. It can be a good performance or a bad performance, right? Which, in other words, become skilled versus unskilled, or it can be a product, a thing, a work of art, that’s either excellent or bad—inferior, right? So, you have that one. And then thirdly, you have good and evil; morally good or morally evil. And then fourth, you have good as ordered, Apollonian, and the opposite is wild, Dionysian, which is a kind of disorder, but it’s a disorder that is creative, OK?

And then finally, you have Obedient and Disobedient, right? And this is the one that, for many, it has the most charge, because remember that movie, They Live, right? And he put on the sunglasses, and you get the “Obey. Obey. Obey.” Right? So, nobody wants to obey, because, you know, who are you obeying? Aliens, right? And that’s now the truth. So, when you obey, you are losing your individuality. No ego wants to obey, because that means you’re the same, you’re no longer different, right? So, “I disobey, therefore I am”.

So on that scale, then, although someone wants to be skilled because they want to be disobedient, they have to develop a whole new style in which unskilled now becomes skilled—you know, Bob Dylan maybe is an example of that, right?—not a skilled singer but look what he did, he revolutionized music, right? Leonard Cohen, someone like that. These are not great voices, but they’re great vocalists. So, you see how the disobedience can move into these other forms and begin to modify them. And so, the wildness and the disobedience become the focus of the ego’s values and intentionality, but in doing that it begins to create more and more obstacles for itself in life, because the more you have to “do it your way”—unless you’re Frank Sinatra and you’ve got the mafia behind you—you’re going to have to have some hardship. It’s not so easy.

And so that’s why the obstacles that arise for someone who has chosen a very independent path, but at the same time doesn’t want to lose the values of all of these higher options of the other spectra, has to find a fine line in order to live life to get the maximal return on one’s investment, right? And all of these have to be coordinated to give you what, for you, is the most profit on the investment.

But what is profit for you, in life? If you ask yourself, what do you want to have gotten out of life on your deathbed that will make you look back on your life and say, “I did it my way and it was great”, you know? “I died happy,” right? Or “No, it didn’t work! I was a failure. I lost. I was a sinner, and I was a fool.” right? I don’t think anybody wants to be on their deathbed, you know, with those feelings, right? So, in a certain way, everyone is trying to live in a way in which their future will bring them to a point where they can say, “Yes, I did it, swaha! I’m done! I went to the other shore and there’s no more to attain.”

So, in order to do that, the ego has to shift from the spectrum of two polarities to a trinity. It has to go from a two-valued logic to a three-valued logic. It has to find the madhyamaka, right? “Where between these two polarities do I stand?” In the same way that you can know that you’re anatomically a male or a female, but that doesn’t necessarily decide if you’re a man or a woman.

And these days man and woman is much more liquid—we could say the anatomy is solid, the question of “am I a man or a woman?” is more liquid, and whether I’m masculine or feminine in any particular aspect or situation is gaseous, right? So again, you have these three states of matter that also have their equivalent in mind and in consciousness.

So, in late Kali Yuga, this third becomes the most important; the madhyamaka. And therefore, the religions of Kali Yuga are all triadic: every God is a Trinity in every religion. So, for example, in the classical period, God was both transcendent and immanent in history. And as a madhyamaka, He created the world, and so He’s transcendent. But as the Creator, He comes into the world and then He’s fully in it and immanent and determining the destiny of the world from within the world.

So, history itself becomes the model of our way of understanding how God works, right? Because God, if there is a God who has created the world, then it has to end in our redemption, right? We have fallen from the creation and now we’re in all of these dualities, but we know that there must be a redemption that comes if God is good.

However, you look at the world nowadays and you say, “You think it’s possible God’s not really good? You know? Or is He sick, you know? Is He not? Well, why is God allowing all of this evil to take over the world, you know? It doesn’t make sense. According to the classical religions, they cannot make a coherent theodicy to explain what’s God’s modus operandi here, and how do I not lose respect for the guy? Right?

But then in the Christian Trinity, of course, Father, Son and Holy Spirit—or Holy Ghost, if you will—but there’s no feminine—where is the Goddess? You see, that was left out. Carl Jung wanted to bring in the feminine and make the Trinity into a Quaternity, but it can’t really function that way. However, the truth is that the Son is actually the Mother. It’s actually—Christ is actually the feminine role in which sameness becomes difference. And the Father, Mother, Child Trinity preceded the Christian one, and this was the Trinity of ancient Egypt: Osiris, Isis and Horus, right? Father, Mother, and Child.

And we have many religions that have that Trinity in other forms. In India, of course, you have Sat Chit Ananda. And in Buddhism, you have the Dharmakaya, the Sambhogakaya, and the Nirmanakaya. In Kashmir Shaivism, you have Shiva, Shakti, and Nara, which is, again, the Transcendent, the Immanent, and the Individual. Nara is the man who tries to modulate, be the madhyamaka between Shiva and Shakti, and to integrate them in one’s consciousness, right? And in Daoism, you have the Taiji, the Yin, the Yang, and they have to be integrated. The circle that contains the Yin and Yang, how does one stay in that state beyond these dualities?

So, in the same way that in classical physics, there were recognized to be these three states of matter: solid, liquid, and gas. But in modern physics, there’s a fourth state—you all know that, right? Plasma is the fourth state of matter, and it was only recently totally incorporated into the physics paradigm. But it is recognized that 99% of the visible universe is made of plasma. And what is plasma? It is matter that has been so superheated that it is paradoxically both a gas and a liquid, and a solid, but neither of them, because what it is, is fusion, the fusion of them all. And it’s plasma that is the source of fusion energy that science is now discovering and trying to make technologically available to us. Because what is fusion energy? It’s the sun, it’s the stars, it’s the nebulae, it’s the interstellar gases. They’re all plasma. And on the Earth, the auroras are made of plasma. But you know what else is made of plasma? Lightning. Plasma is the Vajra.

This is a very important link, because matter has four states, but so does mind. OK? And so, once we understand that, that’s why in yogic terminology, you have Jagrat, Swapna, Sushupti and Turiya—the fourth state, right? That’s the equivalent of plasma. And it’s a state of the fusion, the total fusion of all of those dualities in harmony, and the fusion of the transcendent and the immanent, and the fusion of creation and destruction, and the fusion of the All and the Nothing.

And when our mind reaches a plasmic state of consciousness, that’s what God-consciousness is, that will morph matter itself into plasma, into total plasma, and Sat Yuga will run on plasma energy. That technology can’t be completely engineered in Kali Yuga—they’re leading toward it, but they haven’t been able to do it—but plasma energy will be the operating system of the next age. But it can’t come about until matter itself has become turned into, morphed, transmuted, into plasma, and then again returned into those three states of solid, liquid and gas, but at a higher vibrational frequency, in which they are forms of light rather than forms of solid substance, because matter is only waves, and those waves at a higher vibrational frequency do not become solidified, but remain as luminous crystalline forms that are in themselves not subject to resistance—in that sense, they are both matter and immaterial, simultaneously.

So, in your light body you can pass through walls—there are no resistances—you can teleport, you can recreate a form at a distance because everything is entangled, and that plasma is a field of potentiality that functions in accord with plasmic mind. OK.

So, as we reach this final stage of Kali Yuga, you both have the lowest tamasic level, but you also have the appearance of the fourth stage of the Vajra—of the lightning bolt that in the same way that St. Paul was hit on the road to Damascus and turned into Paul from Saul, and became the great Apostle—in the same way, that same lightning bolt is hitting more and more beings and turning their minds into plasma; into luminous presence that is both stillness and absolute, infinite movement simultaneously. And that’s what Ramana was talking about when he was asked, “What is silence?” It’s infinite speech, eternal infinite eloquence, because it’s God’s Mind. And if you think God’s Mind is boring, then you don’t know what God is. God has the most interesting Mind possible, and when you are fused with the Mind of God, you have infinite capacity, not only to think, but to create things, to create matter out of Mind, because that duality is also fused.

So, as we reach that point of fusing our consciousness with the totality of all of these spectra, we reach a wholeness and a purity of being that contains all possibilities, and is not marred by any contradiction that creates an internal conflict, but instead a possibility of overcoming any and all limitations, because there is no logical point at which something becomes impossible or inconsistent or incomplete, like it does with systems of thought in Kali Yuga. So, the mind overcomes all logical systematicity in its infinite capacity to think in ways that are not limited by language or number.

So, it’s this overcoming of the limitations of symbolic thought as well as of the image—the imaginary layer of consciousness—that enables a fusion of our intelligence at a level that can manifest new forms that become materially present and manifest at the same time that they retain their immaterial basis in Pure Consciousness.

So, this is the final stage at the end of Kali Yuga, and the return to the Singularity. And we can only attain this through reaching a state of total fusion of ego, soul, and Self as a single whole of nirvana and samsara—not as two differences, it’s not a choice—we can’t be liberated from samsara, we have to be liberated in samsara, right? Liberated in the bardo of life but bringing eternal life into time. And that is the ultimate function of Sat Yoga.

Did any of that still make sense? Yeah? In that case, I’m going to quit there while I’m behind, and I’ll let you take over. I’ll give you one more insight.

When we deal with the ego, or we deal with spirit entities that one can be possessed by—that we spoke about—those are mind in solid particulate form; they are particles of mind that are rigid and that remain with a certain lack of plasticity, so they will emanate a certain kind of vibrational frequency. And in the ego, there are a number of different dissociated fragments that are particles of mind that are fixated with certain ideas that can never change. So, we have to de-solidify the internal aspects of the ego, as well as any entities that might have congealed upon and crusted, invaded, or entered into, the auric field of an individual.

Then soul is liquefied mind: soul is mind in a flow state that is always able to function without definition. It’s indeterminacy incarnate, but always able to be the master of any situation by changing, chameleon-like, in accord with what is needed, and to be the yin for the yang that is needed, or the yang for the yin, or on whatever other spectrum, to be able to offer the missing piece. So that’s at the soul level.

Now, when a yogi begins to enter into serious deep tapas—this is the equivalent of the moth going into the flame—when it goes into the flame it can only do it because it’s in a sattvic state—not rajasic or tamasic—but the going into the flame turns it into total chaos, because at the moment that it’s burning, until it has completely burned away, it’s half dead and half alive; it’s half transcendent and half immanent, but it can’t function in either world, it’s like the butterfly that’s not yet a butterfly, but it’s no longer the caterpillar, it’s in the cocoon, but it’s not yet formed, you see? So, it’s in a state of chaos. So, this is the gaseous state of consciousness.

 

So, in order to get to plasma, you have to go through a gaseous chaos of burning away everything that was solid and known, and certain, and that you could depend on, and build your life on—all of that has to be burned away, and in the burning, you feel like you cannot function. You don’t have angel’s wings yet, but you don’t have the butterfly wings either—you can’t function either transcendently or immanently—you’ve burned all your bridges, all your ability at this level, and you haven’t yet got the reward of that sacrifice, and there’s total chaos. And one can only deal with that with total patience, and acceptance, and allow the burning to complete itself. And then it becomes superheated, and the mind becomes plasma, and that’s the Absolute Self. And this has to be the process that we complete, and that’s our alchemy as Sat Yogis.

OK, I hope that’s useful to people, but whether it is or not, that’s what you got today, so tip of the hat to difference. You know, the word madhyamaka, actually a classical Sanskritist pronounces it “mad-yamaka”—and I thought, well, that’s what a POMO Hasid would wear in Israel, so, I had to wear a kind of mad-yamaka today to be the madhyamaka. But we have to be willing to be different from ourselves, and at the same time have enough sameness and consistency that there’s a trustworthiness to the creative difference that emerges, that is somehow able to connect and make sense of the past, but in a new, totally innovative way, that completely changes all of the values and all of the possibilities without losing what was good and what was sustainable, and beautiful and pure, within what is now being morphed from caterpillar to butterfly, or any other form of metamorphosis.

Our metamorphosis is completely beyond our conception. We are becoming unknown to ourselves, and unknown because there’s no pattern in nature that we can mimic. We are entirely unique beings, and that uniqueness means that we have to face life without any model, without any map, and without any preconceived destination. And we discover along the way, through the obstacles we face, where we are actually going. And we only find out really after we’ve arrived, that we are back where we started, and we know it for the first time.

I just stole that from T.S. Eliot, but you know, he was right.

Namaste,

Shunyamurti

Summary: Shunyamurti helps us to understand how the laws of karma operate (only) within the realm of Maya, and how to accept the the mad congruence between destiny and fate—by not using mad-ductive reasoning and maintaining the peace of radical (and sometimes non-rational) acceptance.

So one of the things that I think we would benefit from understanding as deeply as possible is that of maya and the laws of karma. And the laws of karma operate in the realm of maya. They don’t operate beyond the realm of maya. And maya, of course, is illusion. But that illusion is very tenacious, as we know, and it’s not that difficult to fall into it if one’s consciousness gets projected into the phenomenal plane and mistakes it for reality.

And I wanted to point out that we’ve been talking in the retreat about the three types of reasoning that logicians recognize, right? Inductive, deductive, and abductive. But there’s a fourth type of reasoning that is the one that humans actually use. It’s none of those three. That’s what you use on philosophy exams or something. In real life, what I call the fourth type of logical reasoning is not inductive or abductive, but it’s mad-ductive. I would even call it “mad-duct-tape” reasoning, because we try to hold it together through a mad kind of hypothesis. Right? So there’s a kind of normal madness that people actually employ to make their decisions in life. They don’t do it based on reasoning. OK, so I think we all know that. But it might be important to actually study what mad-ductive reasoning is and how it functions and why—although it’s mad—it brings one to a sense of certainty that one is doing the Will of God. Right? Because one feels totally lost and not sure what to do, and it’s only this kind of mad-ductive superposition on the unfoldment of events that can bring it to a conclusion in which one feels like “I couldn’t have done anything else.” Right? And everyone wants to feel that way in order to be able to accept the unfoldment of their fate.

So I want to quote from a passage from an excellent book that I think is actually a storehouse of insights about the law of karma. It’s called Living by the Words of Bhagavan. It’s the story of Annamalai Swami, who is one of the chief disciples of Sri Ramana Maharshi, and he came at a very early point after the establishment of the Ashram in Tiruvannamalai, and he ended up being appointed by Ramana to be the builder of most of the buildings; he constructed them. And what’s interesting about Annamalai, to start with, is that when he was born in a village, maybe forty miles or so away from Tiruvannamalai, a traveling brahmin fortune teller told his parents that he was destined to be a sadhu, and his parents were horrified by this because they wanted him to have a job and make money—they didn’t want him to be wandering out there begging for dinner and all of that—so they did everything possible to dissuade him from being a sadhu and being spiritual. And the father wanted him to follow in his footsteps, and he was a builder, he was a constructionist and built houses. And the last thing Annamalai ever wanted to do was build houses. So, here, he becomes a sadhu, and he ends up having to build the buildings in the Ashram.

So you see how the law of karma doesn’t let you escape from your destiny, but at the same time there’s a kind of mad congruence between your destiny and your fate. Right? How they come together. And so in his acceptance of the fact that he was doing what he hated doing and yet doing what he loved doing simultaneously, he was unable to separate those two aspects of reality which are always bugging the ego, and finally coming to a resolution in which he could totally accept. But it took him a while.

So I want to read this passage that happened in the early days when he first came to the Ashram, and he was not happy there. So let me find this passage. OK, this was, if you have the book, on page 30. Not that you have the book here, but you might have it on your bookshelf and want to go back and check it. Some of you might have it! Synchronicities do happen!

“I was very happy to have found such a great guru as Bhagavan. As soon as I saw him, I felt I was looking at God himself. However, initially I was not very impressed either by the Ashram or by the devotees who had gathered around him. The management seemed to be very autocratic, and most of the devotees didn’t seem to have much interest in the spiritual life. So as far as I could see, they were primarily interested in gossiping.”

Now, you can’t relate to that here, can you? None of us gossip or have any unspiritual attitudes! But, hey, that was Ramana’s ashram! So Annamalai goes on, scandalously.

“These early impressions disturbed me. I thought to myself, ‘Bhagavan is very great, but if I live in the company of these people, I may lose the devotion that I already have.’”

This laughter disturbs me a little bit.

“I came to the conclusion that it would not be spiritually beneficial for me to associate with people who didn’t seem to have much devotion. I know now that this was a very arrogant attitude, but those were my true feelings at the time. These thoughts disturbed me so much that for three or four nights I was unable to sleep. I finally came to the conclusion that I would keep Bhagavan as my guru, but I would live somewhere else.”

“I remember thinking, ‘I will go and do meditation on the Self somewhere else, without having the distracting friendship of any human beings. I will go to an unknown place and meditate on God. I will go for bhiksha,’” which means begging for food, “‘and I’ll lead a solitary life.’”

Right? Live in a cave and be a real sadhu, right.

“I remember thinking, OK, so about three weeks after I first came to the ashram, I left to take up my new life.”

So he was only there three weeks and poof—gone, right?

“So I told no one, not even Bhagavan, about my decision. I left at 1:00 a.m. on a full moon night and started to walk toward town.”

“I went straight through the town past Easanya Math”, which is a monastic institution northeast of Tiruvannamalai, “and I started walking toward Polor. I had no particular destination in mind, I just wanted to get away from the Ashram. I spent the whole night walking and reached Polor, which is a village about 20 miles north of Tiruvannamalai, just after dawn. The walk had made me very hungry, so I decided to go for bhiksha in the town.”

“It was not a great success. I begged at about five hundred different houses, but no one gave me any food.”

That’s very unusual in India at that time.

“One man told me that I should go back to Tiruvannamalai, while another man, who was serving a meal when I approached him, shouted at me, telling me to go away. Eventually I gave up and walked to the outskirts of the town. I found a well in a field, and I spent about a half hour standing in it with the water up to my neck, hoping that the coldness of the water would take my hunger pains away. It didn’t work.”

You see, a little mad-ductive reasoning already starting to take over, right.

“Then I made my way to the Samadhi”, which is a shrine where the corpse or the cremated remains of a saint are. “I went to the Samadhi of Vithoba, who was a saint who had died recently in that town, and sat there for a while. I finally got something to eat when an old lady came to do puja. She looked at me and she said, ‘It seems as if you are very hungry. Your eyes are starting to sink into your face. I don’t have much myself, but I can give you some ragi.’”

That’s millet gruel. It’s not very good, believe me. You’d have to be starving to want to eat it.

“As she was saying that, she gave me about one and a half tumblers of this ragi gruel to drink. It didn’t do much for my hunger pangs, but I was still happy to receive it. The long walk and the lack of food had made me very tired.”

“As I sat there, I began to question the wisdom of leaving Bhagavan. It was clear that things had not turned out in the way that I had expected. This indicated to me that the decision might not have been correct. I formulated a plan which I thought would test whether my decision had been correct or not. I took a large handful of flowers, placed them on the Samadhi of Vithoba, and started to remove them two at a time. I had decided in advance that if there were an odd number of flowers, I would return to Bhagavan, if there were an even number I would carry on with my original plan.”

“When the result indicated that I should go back to Bhagavan, I immediately accepted the decision and started walking toward Tiruvannamalai.”

How many of you have ever made a decision on the basis of something like that? There’s a few honest mad-ductive yogis here. So his karma did seem to indicate that he would be better off going back and that he was going to have a very hard time doing that, living out of the Ashram as he desired. But did he make that decision based on a rational understanding of reality, or was it a non-rational giving into superstition? Well, he goes on.

“Once I had accepted that my prarabdha, my destiny, was to stay with Bhagavan, my luck began to change. As I was walking into town, a hotel owner invited me into his hotel and gave me a free meal and even gave me some money.”

OK!

“He even prostrated to me. He bowed to me as if I was an enlightened saint. So I had decided to return to Tiruvannamalai by train because I wanted to get back as soon as possible, but before I could reach the station, some more people invited me into their house and asked me to eat. I ate a little food there and then excused myself on the grounds that I had just already eaten a big meal. I had decided to try to travel without a ticket because I wrongly assumed that the money I had been given wouldn’t be enough for the journey. My good luck continued on the train—halfway to Tiruvannamalai, a ticket inspector came to inspect all the tickets, I seemed to be invisible to him, for I was the only person in the carriage who was not asked to produce a ticket. A similar thing happened at the end of the journey when I paused in front of the ticket collector on the station platform. He said, ‘You’ve already given your ticket, go. You’re holding up the other people in the line.’ So then, by Bhagavan’s grace, I escaped on both occasions without having to pay.”

Right?

“So I walked the remaining distance to the Ashram. On my arrival, I went straight to Bhagavan, prostrated before him, and told him everything that happened. Bhagavan confirmed it was my destiny to stay at Ramanashram. He said, ‘You have work to do here. If you try to leave without doing the jobs you’re destined for you, where can you go?’”

OK, so that’s how karma works, OK? Now, he was pretty certain by the way he was treated on the way back as if he was already an enlightened being and given all kinds of miraculous help that he had made the right decision. So he had no doubts, right?

So karma will work that way, but does it work that way because of external forces? Or was it his own projections, and his own attitude, and his own subconscious conflict with the act of leaving the Ashram that had produced the difficulties leaving, and all of the great events of support that he got on coming back? Right?

So a psychoanalyst would obviously analyze this event differently than would a mystic or a yogi, but nonetheless, this is the kind of event that determines the course of our lives, rather than any kind of a logical process of deciding the pros and cons of some program. Right?

So I think that understanding how maya works and how we are participants in the creation of the events without realizing that we are, and then getting the feedback from the phenomenal plane that is actually expressing our innermost yearning, that integrates and brings to fruition a melding of the conflicting drives in the conscious and subconscious, with our superconscious destiny, is what brings wholeness if we don’t resist it—if we actually obey the signs and wonders that we are given from the world as a message that comes from God, or is the way that the Dao is unfolding.

So there’s a kind of sanity that comes from being mad, and that alone can bring one into a state of harmony with one’s world and one’s conditions of life, and a full acceptance of how it unfolds in perfection without a constant sense of doubt: “Should I be here? Should I go? Should I do something else?”

So he was fortunate that destiny would not let him leave. The unfortunate ones are those who do get to leave without being stopped, and then have to discover things along the way that they might have learned more easily at the ashram. But nonetheless, everyone’s destiny comes out of their individual relationship to the world, and to their own internal drive complexes, that create reality as a—with a look that brings about a kind of a compromise between the positive and the negative, between what is good in a situation and seeing what is bad, and making a decision of does the bad outweigh the good, or does the cons outweigh the pros, that would cause me to make a decision to go elsewhere or to do something else other than what I had thought would be my destiny?

So this is the kind of question that’s always going on somehow in the subtext of every ego-mind. And until that kind of internal disharmony can be resolved, one doesn’t have a peaceful relationship to one’s unfoldment of one’s life. So yoga will give you that peace if you can be in acceptance with the mad-ductive responsibility to interpret the signs in a way that will serve your highest unfoldment of surrender to the Will of God, even if that Will looks like it is presented in a way that is non-rational. But by following the clues that the world is giving you, you will get a strong sense of what the Dao is opening to you, and what windows of opportunity you should leap through, and which ones you should close and say “no thanks” to. And those kinds of intuitions are part of what develops when the soul becomes more sensitive to the nature of how reality is reflected in appearance.

So that brings me to the next announcement, which is that we’re doing a very soft launch of a new book—so soft that it’s weightless, and isn’t really even happening. But the second volume of the Gems of Wisdom series of the collected essays that were done, starting back in 2002 and 2003, we’re now in volume two, and I had to get it out of my space so I could go on.

So I have no emotional relation to this book, and it’s very odd because it’s a very emotion-filled book, but somehow it’s just something that has passed through that has to be given. And I think it may be helpful to some people, but because it’s a book about maya, really, and about the overcoming of maya, but mostly about the way that maya functions in the life of the ego, and even of the soul level of consciousness. Somehow, it’s a book that I think one can benefit from appreciating, and in the same way that one outgrows frames of reference, or paradigms of life, and enters into more spacious and more deep and more meaningful ones, I think that the reading of the book may serve someone to let go of their own veils, and unveil the Real behind whatever is the pattern of belief that is motivating the consciousness, to think of itself as a certain kind of person in a certain kind of world, and to recognize that all of that is projected and none of it is based on the Real, it’s based on thought patterns.

So The Seven Vales of Maya is the title, and the subtitle is Eldritch Essays, by this character called Shunyamurti. Now I want to explain this word “Eldritch” and why I chose it. It’s an old word, and it comes originally from elf-reich, OK? Meaning, “the Kingdom of the Elves”. In other words, it comes from an enchanted world, a world that is filled with beings who are magical. The essays in this volume come from Greek mythology, and Greek mythology is filled with all kinds of nymphs, water nymphs, and woodland nymphs, and of course there are sirens, and you have in Olympus, you have not only the gods, but you have the graces and the muses, and you have semi- and demigods and all kinds of hybrids. And of course you have Poseidon, the ocean god, and you have Thanatos, the Lord of Death, and you have the rulers of the underworld, Hades and Persephone. So you have a world filled with magical beings.

And I chose Greek mythology rather than Indian mythology to use as the basis of trying to explain the developmental process of the human through the different veils of maya that one goes through as one’s consciousness deepens, and one perceives the magical nature of the world, but then passes through that into a more non-magical and scientific kind of mode of perception, and then transcends even that into a more metaphysical and analytic kind of consciousness. At the end of Kali Yuga, in which there’s a linguistic turn, and one is recognizing that the world is based on representations, but that the signifiers of language are always sliding over the signified, and one doesn’t always know what they mean by what they say and what they think. And so one becomes aware of the confusions even within rational thought, because the connection between what you think and what those thoughts actually mean and refer to within the plane of maya are in a state of slippage and indeterminacy—they are not as certain as we tend to want to believe.

And so we are led into cognitive errors through actually accurate thinking, but we’re basing the thinking on the words and not on the reference of those words. So we can be confused if someone tells us they’re giving us a vaccine, when the word “vaccine” now means something very different—it now means, right, a genetically modifying device that will put microchips and nanobots into you—but the word “vaccine” doesn’t tend to mean that to people, and so if they assume that the signifier refers to its old signified, they may make an error in judgment, right?

So it is the play between these two planes of representation that ruling elites tend to use in order to develop mind control over subjects who have a tendency to have a naive relationship with language, and can easily be manipulated by signifiers that sound good—“democracy” may sound good, but that signifier now tends to mean arbitrary tyranny, but we’re still in the “free world”—that means we’re enslaved—but the signifiers are accurate if you understand what they mean. Indeed, the injections are safe and effective if your goal is depopulation.

So the recognition of the relationship of these levels of signifier and signified that will give you an understanding of how you have to respond to the various calls of the media and the Big Brother in advising you as to what to do and how to live. So I used Greek mythology rather than Indian, because, you know, we’ve all seen the Mahabharata film recently, and the Logos of ancient India is very different from the Logos of ancient Greece. They do have things in common—they’re both magical worlds—but in ancient Greece, you wouldn’t have a wife blindfolding herself in order to be in resonance with a blind husband and share his blindness—she would instead want to be his eyes and take care of him, or else leave him, but she would at least not want to blind herself. She would follow an entirely different logic in her way of relating to disability, let’s say, and to the dharma of loyalty.

And in many ways, the kind of dharmic intentionality in ancient India did not carry over into the Greek world, even though the Greek world is an Aryan split off community, but nonetheless, because of their nomadic nature and because they became a seafaring culture living on Greek Isles, their actual relationship to reality became very different than an agricultural society in a landlocked area. And the Greek, let’s say, not just the Logos, but the umwelt, became the basis of European social development, and this led to what, in modern times, became colonialism and imperialism, and technological development, because there was a will to power that was present within the Greek culture, in which there was a lot of warfare, much more so—even though the Mahabharata is about a war, but nonetheless, the culture was very literally Spartan in its formation of a social order as a war machine.

And so that kind of an appropriation of techne, even within a magical context, was already present within ancient Greece, and it’s that attitude that became the basis of the possessive tendencies—the greed, the tendency of control of territory, etc.—that we are, of course, still dealing with in a much more complicated way today. But I felt that because of the Europeanization of the globe, through the globalization of capitalism in the end of Kali Yuga, that this was a model of intellectual development that was more relatable to readers in the West.

And the different mythological constructs were the equivalent of modern psychoanalysis. In fact, it’s no accident that Freud stole from Greek mythology his main concepts, right, the narcissism from the myth of Narcissus, the Oedipus complex, etc., they came from there, and Carl Jung stole even more from the Greek mythological tradition as representing our own archetypal subconscious. And so there is a through-line between modern depth psychology and the ancient mythological psychology, that was taught in a different way, but was, I think, even more descriptive and more effective in its presentation of how a complex affects one’s life course.

And so what I did, and originally back in 2004, for the most part, was I wrote five of these essays, and I’ve extracted them from all the other essays written in that period because they shared that theme, but I added the final two that were never actually posted back then. And they are not mythological because they are the point where consciousness leaves mythology and enters metaphysics, and takes the linguistic turn into the Logos and the Ontos, the drive to understand one’s being, not one’s becoming.

And so this is a kind of arc of development of consciousness to its final phase, that we are now in at the end of the Iron Age. And because the myths are very ironic, in a way, I think that’s a very important concept—I would even call this—not the Iron Age—but the Irony Age, because everything is totally ironic and, you know, an ironic expression says the opposite of what it means, like the vaccines are safe and effective, etc.—and so there is an ironic tint to everything that you hear within the media that often is telling you the truth in the form of a lie. And very often fiction reveals much more truth than nonfiction can, and so these fictional scenarios that the Greek myths comprise are often very revealing in ways that a logical or philosophical treatise could not present.

So I’m hoping that the book will be useful and good for a laugh or two, and for an ironic understanding of one’s own, let’s say, misdirections, misunderstandings of oneself, that can help unveil what is implicit but never fully recognized in one’s trajectory of narrative development, of the representational aspect of one’s ego.

Namaste,

Shunyamurti

And you must be totally free of any rigidity, or any memory, or any desire, in order to achieve the Presence to God that is in unity with the Godself.

And it’s when this is achieved that one is then able to evolve one’s inherent desire for anarchy. Because every ego wants anarchy: it wants to be the law, it wants to be God. But until that is translated into wanting to be God without the ego, not the ego as God, that anarchy evolves into sophiocracy, and now there can be an order of wisdom and a legitimate hierarchy of power and of goodness that can be translated into social terms. And only then can a Kingdom of Heaven be established, and law prevented from ever becoming oppressive, and love kept pure of lust and aggression and unable to produce divine love relationships. So until we have valorized humility over mastery, and all of the transvaluations that go with that, and are implied by that, we will not be able to attain that.

Now, here we are at this moment, at the end of the kalpa, at the point when the ego is in its lowest, most tamasic point, and it has literally gone mad, and it cannot be controlled, it can’t be trained, it can’t be refined, because it doesn’t want any of that—it just wants its freedom, its control, its power, its wishful thinking, to be able to be enacted. It cannot handle the effect of Real 1, of the forces that are now impinging upon one’s individual freedom at the level of body, because of the biopolitics, etc., and at the level of mind, because of the disordered nature of the consciousness.

And so the enslavement of the ego to the other—because when you have lost your intelligence and you live in a state of stupidity, you are dependent on the other. And so your desire for freedom actually leads you to join the herd mind and to “trust the science”, and to give up your power, and to only care about whether you can choose what toppings you want on your pizza, but you can’t choose how you’re going to live in the social order, that’s all going to be decided by arbitrary decrees, and you’ll have no say in it, but you’ll be too busy eating your pizza and drinking beer to even care about it. And so that’s how they do it since the Roman times, “bread and circuses”, it’s just become a little more sophisticated these days, with cocaine and other types of amusements, but it’s the same basic idea. And so people have become enslaved, and they have lost the ability to regulate their own habits and their own minds, they have become addicted, and addictive personalities, and out of touch with reality and unable to order themselves.

So, in this state it becomes a difficulty of almost impossibility to become free. It’s at this point that we have to make the decision—the only possible decision—since the ego can’t be improved, it can’t be refined, it can’t be transformed anymore. It’s become too rotten, too lost, too incoherent—the only thing left to us is ego death. The only choice, the only rational choice, that can be made, is for the ego to be taken by the soul and surrender to God. The soul has the power to do that, but it will have to overcome and not pay attention to the resistance of the ego, and surrender its thoughts, its desires, its attitudes, its opinions, all of that to the silence of the presence of God.

This would be impossible to accomplish except for one factor; and the one factor is that when you attempt to do it seriously, with sincere yearning from your heart, even though you will meet resistance, what will happen at a certain point when the soul’s seriousness of purpose has been established—that you’re going to fight, even if it’s a tug of war—you know, the devas and the asuras are always shown in a tug of war with the serpent of maya between them, and that’s the tug of war that you will have within. But at a certain moment, that tug of war becomes a churning of the ocean of consciousness, and out of it come two things: one is poison. That poison will have to be taken and transformed, and when it’s transformed, it becomes nectar. It becomes the nectar of immortality. And what will be given to us by the grace of God if our struggle is true, and is unrelenting, is the taste of the nectar of bliss, the bliss of the immortality of our true divine nature.

And it’s the taste of that nectar that will motivate us to take that serpent and completely defeat the opposition of the asuric tendencies of the ego, because we will be nourished and empowered by that nectar. That nectar is what Christ was anointed with, Christ means “the anointed one”. We all have to be anointed with that nectar, and it has to be absorbed into the brain. We have to be saturated in it, until we are drunk and mad with divine love, and with the Presence of God, and the ego completely dissolved and disintegrated, and annihilated in that nectarian environment.

That’s what we have to do in meditation, and that will lead us to the liberation in the bardo of life, that will turn life into a kingdom of God.

Namaste,

Shunyamurti
